description: From Middle English *gloten, glouten, from Old Norse glotta (“to grin, smile scornfully”) or Old English *glotian, both from Proto-Germanic *glutōną (“to stare”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰel- (“to shine”), related to dialectal Swedish glotta, glutta (“to peep”), Middle High German glutzen, glotzen (“to stare”), Modern German glotzen (“to gawk, goggle”).

entries.meaning: An act or instance of gloating.

verbs.description: gloat (third-person singular simple present gloats, present participle gloating, simple past and past participle gloated)

entries.meaning: To exhibit a conspicuous (sometimes malevolent) pleasure or sense of self-satisfaction, often at an adversary's misfortune.
examples: You did well to win the game, but there's no need to gloat about it.

entries.meaning: To triumph, crow, relish, glory, revel.
